FAQ.question: What are Hydra / FTL maps?
FAQ.answer: Hydra and FTL maps show water body boundaries, lake extents, feeder channels, and buffer zones to identify construction-restricted regions.

FAQ.question: Why are Hydra / FTL checks important?
FAQ.answer: They help ensure a property is not located on lake beds, water channels, or protected zones that may lead to demolition, legal disputes, or denied approvals.

FAQ.question: What details are required to check Hydra / FTL data?
FAQ.answer: Only the Village or Division details (and optionally survey/location details for precision).

FAQ.question: Does falling in FTL mean construction is banned?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Construction on lake beds or inside FTL zones is typically prohibited unless government-approved exceptions exist.

FAQ.question: What is the difference between FTL and buffer zone?
FAQ.answer: FTL refers to the maximum water spread level of a lake, while buffer zones are regulated margins outside the water body for protection and flood safety.

FAQ.question: Can a property be legally registered if it falls under FTL?
FAQ.answer: Registration may still occur, but construction permissions and development approvals can be denied or challenged.

FAQ.question: How does JaaGa verify Hydra / FTL status?
FAQ.answer: JaaGa cross-references government hydrology datasets, lake maps, planning boundaries, and GIS overlays for accurate validation.

FAQ.question: Is Hydra / FTL the same as prohibited land?
FAQ.answer: No. Hydra/FTL relates to water-body regulated zones. Prohibited land refers to assigned, government, temple, forest or legally restricted land.

FAQ.question: Is Hydra / FTL proof of ownership?
FAQ.answer: No. It only indicates water-body classification. Ownership proof comes from Sale Deeds and registration records.

FAQ.question: Is data from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. All classifications are sourced from official planning bodies and publicly available hydrology datasets.
